Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dimensions NASA: Linking remotely sensed optical diversity to genetic, phylogenetic and functional diversity to predict ecosystem processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use three biodiversity manipulations at the Cedar Creek Ecosystem Science Reserve to test whether plant diversity (including genotypes within species, species with different functions, and species from different evolutionary lineages) can be detected remotely at multiple spatial scales. The study will measure biodiversity from the sky and space by remotely sensing the reflected light spectra of plants and investigate the consequences of biodiversity for ecosystem and global processes. Project scientists from four institutions will investigate linkages between plant biodiversity, soil microbe diversity and ecosystem function. These efforts will serve in the development of airborne and satellite platforms that can routinely monitor biodiversity and provide critical experimental evidence for the concept of surrogacy, i.e., that one metric of biodiversity can be used to provide information about others.

The project will transform methods for detecting changes in biodiversity worldwide and will provide numerous training opportunities in science, technology and math (STEM) for young scientists. Results will be integrated into the Cedar Creek Schoolyard Ecology program and a NASA-funded STEM Education Center to train Native American reservation teachers. Citizen scientists will be engaged through the MN Phenology Network. Data and research outcomes will be archived in publically accessible data repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current mass extinction event necessitates that we supplement traditional ground-based observations with new technologies to understand the scope of biodiversity loss across large spatial scales at fine taxonomic resolution. New advances in remote sensing techniques have vast potential for observing and understanding ecological systems. We have the potential to employ remote sensing techniques to quickly measure small differences in biodiversity across large spatial scales. Much of the variation in diversity that is important to how ecosystems process energy and matter is reflected in variation in plant leaf traits that are directly measurable via various remote sensing techniques. We worked with an interdisciplinary team to explore how variation in plant reflectance (plant spectra) is related to above- and belowground biodiversity and functioning. In grassland systems, we demonstrated that plant spectra (or leaf reflectance) was closely tied to aboveground diversity and function. In addition, variation in belowground microbial communities and belowground function was also measurable via plant spectra. These results demonstrate that plants act as biological indicators of above- and belowground processes, and that remotely-sensed plant spectra capture much of the biologically relevant variation in aboveground plant biomass. Specifially, plant specta can act a surrogates for aboveground biomass, diversity, and chemistry, as well as several microbially-driven belowground processes. These findings open future research opportunities to explore biodiversity and ecosystem processes at both large spatial scales and fine taxonomic resolution. Advances in applying remote sensing to biology systems will aid us in understanding how changes in biodiversity across and within species affect fundamental ecosystem processes such as carbon and nitrogen cycling.

In addition to the intellectual merit of the project, this research made significant broader impacts to society through training undergraduate and graduate students. Numerous graduate and undergraduate students were directly involved with high-impact research. ASU is a primarily undergraduate institution while the collaborative institutions were all large, research-intensive universities. Several ASU students were first-generation university students. Involvement with this project has helped these students to begin successful postgraduate experiences in graduate education as well as careers in NGO, governmental, and environmental sectors.

As a collaborative project, this funding resulted in 18 collaborative publications, with several more in preparation. We have presented talks at numerous scientific meetings, and incorporated our research into undergraduate and graduate courses, reaching hundreds of students at ASU alone. Our data are available in online repositories for further exploration and collaborative research efforts.
